title: How to Draw the Dark Mark

steps.title: Get a reference image if you can, then lightly map out the general shapes.
steps.content: Get a reference image if you can, then lightly map out the general shapes. This image has a circle for the skull, two more circles for the snake's body, and a hook for the snake's head.

steps.title: Draw the outline of a skull.
steps.content: Draw the outline of a skull. A circle and chin will do. It doesn't have to fit your earlier circle exactly; that's just a rough guideline.

steps.title: Draw the basic facial features.
steps.content: Draw the basic facial features. Two round, oblong shapes will work for the eye-sockets and a round triangle represents the nose. Two slanted "L's" for the cheekbones will suffice.

steps.title: Outline the upper jaw.
steps.content: Outline the upper jaw. At this point, it should slightly resemble Darth Vader's helmet.

steps.title: Make some more light guidelines, but detail the position of the snake this time.
steps.content: Make some more light guidelines, but detail the position of the snake this time. It protrudes from the skull and then twists on itself into a figure eight. It should follow the general path of the guide you made earlier. Give yourself a guide for the snake's head. We see a circle for the skull and a rectangle for the jaws. What about you?

steps.title: Edit the spots where the lines cross.
steps.content: Edit the spots where the lines cross. Erase as needed so that the snake overlaps itself.

steps.title: Sketch the places where the snake turns, exposing its belly when it had shown its back and vice versa.
steps.content: Sketch the places where the snake turns, exposing its belly when it had shown its back and vice versa. Erase your original guidelines while leaving one for the chin.

steps.title: Refine these lines and darken them.
steps.content: Refine these lines and darken them. Use your reference image to draw the snake's head.

steps.title: Add some patterns and shading to the snake.
steps.content: Add some patterns and shading to the snake. The canon snake has patterns that look like smooshed together hills, in either a group of one, two, or three, in a dark color. A lighter color is used to make spots inside of those hills, as well as to color the surrounding skin.

steps.title: Shade the skull.
steps.content: Shade the skull. Everything inside the outline of the mandible (lower jaw) should be pitch black.
